results.headline: The High Road Through a Struggle Is Never Easy to Navigate
results.summary_short: “Mandela: Long Walk to Freedom” is a stately film biography of Nelson Mandela, starring Idris Elba.

results.headline: The Many Shapes of Time
results.summary_short: The Canadian director Peter Mettler explores the human perception of time in his experimental documentary, “The End of Time.”

results.headline: Holiday Movie or Music Video?
results.summary_short: Singers known and not as well known try to give Harry Connick Jr.’s character the Christmas spirit in “Angels Sing,” set in Austin, Tex.

results.headline: Build a Beach, Rinse, Repeat
results.summary_short: “Shored Up” is a thought-provoking documentary about the folly of shoreline construction in the Hurricane Sandy age.

results.headline: A Long Walk for Glaciers
results.summary_short: “Pad Yatra: A Green Odyssey” documents a trek through the Himalayas by a large group of people whose eco-friendly intentions.

results.headline: A Lo-Fi Idol, Fondly Considered
results.summary_short: Kathleen Hanna, the feminist punk hero of the 1990s and beyond, is the main event of the fast-moving documentary “The Punk Singer.”

results.summary_short: “Frozen,” from Disney, departs a bit from the company’s traditional princess formula.

results.headline: A Couple Living in a State of Nostalgia
results.summary_short: “Cousin Jules,” first released 40 years ago, is a documentary that follows an elderly couple living in a French village.

results.headline: Down in the Bayou, Mellow They’re Not
results.summary_short: “Homefront,” with Winona Ryder, James Franco and Jason Statham, packs plenty of drugs and violence into its Louisiana setting.

results.headline: Chance Encounter Goes Viral; Cyberbullying Is Next
results.summary_short: A woman whose chance behavior goes viral online discovers the consequences when she’s subject to cyberbullying in “Caught in the Web,” a Chinese film directed by Chen Kaige.

results.headline: Christmas in Harlem, and O Come, All Ye Songs
results.summary_short: The musical “Black Nativity,” set mostly in contemporary Harlem, is directed by Kasi Lemmons.

results.headline: Nasty Nuns Can’t Shake a Faith
results.summary_short: Stephen Frears’s “Philomena” follows a Irishwoman forced to give up her son for adoption in the 1950s and the freelance reporter who helps her search for him.

results.headline: The Way They Used to Race (and Die)

results.headline: Striking Where Myth Meets Moment
results.summary_short: “The Hunger Games: Catching Fire,” the second film in the series, brings back Jennifer Lawrence as Katniss Everdeen, but has a new director, Francis Lawrence.

results.headline: Singing of the Cartels, and Investigating Them

results.headline: An Unusual Health Care Worker

results.headline: Enemies, Abroad and at Home
results.summary_short: “JFK: A President Betrayed” considers the hostile opposition John F. Kennedy faced in trying to shift American foreign policy.

results.headline: An Old Town With New Problems
results.summary_short: “It’s Better to Jump” allows Arab residents to express their concerns about the gentrification of their city, part of which is a Unesco World Heritage site.
